repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
`client.messages` could grow unbounded because the default handler only
added new messages, never removing them.

A user either had to consume the messages by calling
`vim.lsp.util.get_progress_messages` or by manually removing them from
`client.messages.progress`. If they didn't do that, using LSP
effectively leaked memory.

To fix this, this deprecates the `messages` property and instead adds a
`progress` ring buffer that only keeps at most 50 messages. In addition
it deprecates `vim.lsp.util.get_progress_messages` in favour of a new
`vim.lsp.status()` and also promotes the `LspProgressUpdate` user
autocmd to a regular autocmd to allow users to pattern match on the
progress kind.

Also closes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/20327

comment_data.body: Whether it is useful to support client_name filtering. When starting multiple clients, I only want to focus on the main client's messages.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -891,6 +894,55 @@ function lsp.start(config, opts)
   return client_id
 end
 
+--- Consumes the latest progress messages from all clients and formats them as string.
+--- Empty if there are no clients or if no new messages
+---
+---@return string
+function lsp.status()

@@ -142,6 +144,9 @@ release.
   - |nvim_win_get_option()|	Use |nvim_get_option_value()| instead.
   - |nvim_win_set_option()|	Use |nvim_set_option_value()| instead.
 
+• vim.lsp functions:
+  - |vim.lsp.util.get_progress_messages()|	Use |vim.lsp.status()| instead.

comment_data.body:
probably don't need "Update" in this one (if any).

```suggestion
    LspProgress=true,
```

We can follow up in a separate PR and add some filters via a `opts` table if it turns out to be required. Given that this function consumes the messages and that common second clients like null-ls probably have no progress messages I'm not sure if this will be required

@@ -891,6 +894,55 @@ function lsp.start(config, opts)

 end
 
+--- Consumes the latest progress messages from all clients and formats them as string.

+---

@@ -117,19 +117,21 @@ internally and are no longer exposed as part of the API. Instead, use
 - *vim.lsp.diagnostic.set_virtual_text()*
 
 LSP FUNCTIONS
-- *vim.lsp.buf.range_code_action()*	Use |vim.lsp.buf.code_action()| with
-					the `range` parameter.
-- *vim.lsp.util.diagnostics_to_items()*	Use |vim.diagnostic.toqflist()| instead.
-- *vim.lsp.util.set_qflist()*		Use |setqflist()| instead.
-- *vim.lsp.util.set_loclist()*		Use |setloclist()| instead.
-- *vim.lsp.buf_get_clients()*		Use |vim.lsp.get_active_clients()| with
-					{buffer = bufnr} instead.
-- *vim.lsp.buf.formatting()*		Use |vim.lsp.buf.format()| with
-					{async = true} instead.
-- *vim.lsp.buf.formatting_sync()*	Use |vim.lsp.buf.format()| with
-					{async = false} instead.
-- *vim.lsp.buf.range_formatting()*	Use |vim.lsp.formatexpr()|
-					or |vim.lsp.buf.format()| instead.
+- *vim.lsp.buf.range_code_action()*		Use |vim.lsp.buf.code_action()| with
+						the `range` parameter.
+- *vim.lsp.util.diagnostics_to_items()*		Use |vim.diagnostic.toqflist()| instead.
+- *vim.lsp.util.set_qflist()*			Use |setqflist()| instead.
+- *vim.lsp.util.set_loclist()*			Use |setloclist()| instead.
+- *vim.lsp.buf_get_clients()*			Use |vim.lsp.get_active_clients()| with
+						{buffer = bufnr} instead.
+- *vim.lsp.buf.formatting()*			Use |vim.lsp.buf.format()| with
+						{async = true} instead.
+- *vim.lsp.buf.formatting_sync()*		Use |vim.lsp.buf.format()| with
+						{async = false} instead.
+- *vim.lsp.buf.range_formatting()*		Use |vim.lsp.formatexpr()|
+						or |vim.lsp.buf.format()| instead.
+- *vim.lsp.util.get_progress_messages()*	Use |vim.lsp.status()| or access
+						`process` of |vim.lsp.client|

comment_regular_data.body:
> A user either had to consume the messages by calling
vim.lsp.util.get_progress_messages or by manually removing them from
client.messages.progress. If they didn't do that, using LSP
effectively leaked memory.

Does it make sense to turn `lsp.util.get_progress_messages` into a shim around `lsp.status()` until it's removed/deprecated officially?

> > A user either had to consume the messages by calling
> > vim.lsp.util.get_progress_messages or by manually removing them from
> > client.messages.progress. If they didn't do that, using LSP
> > effectively leaked memory.
> 
> Does it make sense to turn `lsp.util.get_progress_messages` into a shim around `lsp.status()` until it's removed/deprecated officially?

I added a fixup that changes `get_progress_messages` to also consume client.progress, so it still returns messages.


What's maybe a bit odd about `status()` and `client.progress` is that depending on how frequently they are called you observe incomplete message parts. E.g. a `report` or `end` without having the `title` from `begin` because that was already consumed in a prior `status()` call. This will lead to messages that miss the title prefix.

We could solve this by adding a `client.progress.pending`, which keeps a `token → messages` mapping, similar to how the existing handler worked, with the key difference that once it receives a `end`, it removes the entry and pushes the entries into the new `client.progress` ring-buffer. So the ringbuffer would contain tables of complete message sequences, with 1 begin, n-reports, and 1 end.

Upside: The status messages look nicer
Downside: If a language server misses to send a `end` message there would still be a memory leak

> We could solve this by adding a client.progress.pending, which keeps a token → messages mapping, similar to how the existing handler worked, with the key difference that once it receives a end, it removes the entry and pushes the entries into the new client.progress ring-buffer. So the ringbuffer would contain tables of complete message sequences, with 1 begin, n-reports, and 1 end.
> Upside: The status messages look nicer
> Downside: If a language server misses to send a end message there would still be a memory leak

This actually doesn't work nicely either, as it would result in `status()` showing all the messages together at once instead of showing continuous updates

But I've another idea that I'll give a try

> But I've another idea that I'll give a try

I added a `title` carry-over logic from `begin` to `report` and `end` messages, this way the display can be done the same way as previously while still fixing the unbound memory growth, assuming that language servers behave well and send a `end`.

I think this should be good to go now

Hi, this PR will have performance issue, the for loop calculation is **O(n \* m)**, where **n** is active lsp clients count, **m** is token count of each lsp client.

In my practice, **O(n \* m)** calculation will block neovim statusline refreshing, then block user operations.

In my plugin, I use a 2-layer map to cache all lsp progress messages, thus transform the time complexity to less than O(n), please see: https://github.com/linrongbin16/lsp-progress.nvim

On the other hand, 2-layer cached map will use more memory, so it's a trade-off on memory or CPU. But for most desktop machines, memory is not as critical as operation blocking.

Most users have 1 or maybe two clients and the token count is usually small, for small numbers, `O(n * m)` is still close to 1.

Tables require hash code computations and use more memory due to the hashing, and have worse cache locality. It's not clear cut that another approach would be faster, but you're welcome to show with benchmarks that another approach would lead to meaningful speedups

title: feat(lsp)!: add vim.lsp.status, client.progress and promote LspProgressUpdate
